questions.question: Question 1: The origin of social and preventive medicine dates back to the:
questions.explanation:
The origin of social and preventive medicine dates back to the 18th century. It began even before 
the germ theory had been proposed.

questions.question: Question 2: Which medicine claims to be the world’s first organized body of medical knowledge?
questions.explanation:
Chinese medicine claims to be the world's first organized body of medical knowledge. It dates 
back to 2700 B.C. They are also considered to be the pioneers of immunization (used variolation 
against smallpox). Modern Chinese medicine includes barefoot doctors and acupuncture.

questions.question: Question 3: All of the following are true about the ministry of AYUSH except:

options.a: It was formed in 2014 in India for education and research on AYUSH
options.b: It aims to mainstream AYUSH as part of the National Rural Health Mission
options.c: It was previously known as department of Indian system of medicine and homeopathy
options.d: It regulates the fields of Ayurveda, Yoga, Homeopathy and Siddha only

questions.explanation:
The Ministry of AYUSH was established to regulate the fields of Ayurveda, Yoga, and 
Naturopathy, Unani, Siddha, and Homeopathy. It was formed in 2014 in India for the development of education and research in AYUSH. It was 
previously known as the Department of Indian System of Medicine and Homeopathy 
(ISM&H). It aims to mainstream AYUSH as part of the National Rural Health Mission 
(NRHM). The Ayurveda, Siddha, and Yoga systems of medicine are of Indian origin. Ayurveda means 
knowledge of life. Its origin can be traced back to 5000 B.C (Vedic times). The medical knowledge 
in the Atharvaveda eventually developed into Ayurveda. The Unani system is of Greek origin.

questions.question: Question 4: Samuel Hahnemann is referred to as the founding father of:
questions.explanation:
Samuel Hahnemann is the founding father of homeopathy. He was German. There are 3 principles in homeopathy: • Similia similibus curentur or human drug pathogenicity study: Treatment of disease using small 
amounts of drug that, in healthy people, would produce similar symptoms of the disease itself. • A single medicine is used for the treatment. • The minimum dose of the drug should be used. 12 
Sold by @itachibot Scientist/ Doctor

questions.question:
Question 5: The Tridosha theory of disease explains disease as a disturbance in the equilibrium of the 
three humors. To which system of medicine does this theory belong to?
questions.explanation:
Tridosha theory of disease belongs to Ayurveda. It explains disease as a disturbance in the 
equilibrium of the three humors, namely: • Vata (wind) 13 
Sold by @itachibot • Pitta (gall) • Kapha (mucus). A healthy person has a perfect balance of these humors. This theory is similar to the Unani-tibb system of medicine which is based on four humors.

questions.question: Question 6: Which system of medicine originated in Tamil–speaking areas in south India?
questions.explanation:
The Siddha system of medicine originated from Tamil culture. It means achievement. This system believes that sociodemographic, psychological, and physiological factors related to a 
person must be taken into account while deciding the medical treatment. They believe that 
disease is a disturbance in the equilibrium of three humors called vaadham, pittam, and kapham.

questions.question: Question 7: Where did the Unani–Tibb system of medicine originate?
questions.explanation:
The Unani-Tibb system of medicine originated in ancient Greece. The Greeks believed that matter was made up of four elements. These elements had certain 
qualities that were represented in the body by the 4 humors and also determined the person's 
temperament. Eleme

questions.question:
Question 8: Inoculating a person with a small amount of infective material to obtain protection against it 
was first pioneered by:
questions.explanation:
The procedure described is immunization. It was first pioneered in ancient Chinese medicine. 
They practiced variolation to prevent smallpox. Note: Edward Jenner discovered the smallpox vaccine in 1796, the first vaccine to be 
discovered. He also coined the term vaccination. 14 
Sold by @itachibot Scientist/ Doctor

questions.question: Question 9: Who is referred to as the father of Indian medicine?
questions.explanation:
Charaka is the father of Indian medicine. He wrote the Charaka Samhita. Note: Susruta is known as the father of Indian surgery. He is depicted in the following image. 15

questions.question: Question 10: Who was responsible for the first codification of medical practice?
questions.explanation:
Hammurabi, a Mesopotamian king was responsible for the first codification of medical practice. Known as the Babylonian Code, it contained laws for the conduct of physicians, health practices, 
costs, and penalties of harmful therapy. Scientist/ Doctor

questions.question: Question 11: Who is known as the first true epidemiologist in the history of medicine?
questions.explanation:
Hippocrates is known as the first true epidemiologist in the history of medicine. He is also known 
as the father of medicine. He introduced the concept of the relationship between the environment and human health. He 
was the author of Airs, Water, and Places, a treatise on social medicine and hygiene as well as 
the Corpus Hippocraticum, a collection of 72 volumes of clinical case histories. He also developed the Hippocratic Oath, which is considered the keystone of medical ethics. Scientist/ Doctor

questions.question: Question 12: Who compiled the 21 volume encyclopedia known as 'the Canon of Medicine'?
questions.explanation:
Avicenna compiled the book, the Canon of Medicine which is a 21 volume encyclopedia. He was a Persian who was also known as lbn Sina. He was the leader of Arabic medicine. The 
Arabs invented the art of prescription writing. Scientist/ Doctor

questions.explanation:

questions.question: Question 14: The father of public health is:
questions.explanation:
The father of public health is cholera, the disease, not a person. John Snow studied the epidemiology of cholera in London from 1848 to 1854 and established the 
role of polluted drinking water in the spread of cholera. He is called the father of modern 
epidemiology. He also calculated the dose of ether and chloroform as surgical anesthesia. Note: Tuberculosis is called the barometer of social welfare. Scientist/ Doctor

questions.question: Question 15: Match the following scientists with their discoveries:
questions.explanation:
The discoveries of the given scientists are as follows: • John Snow - association of cholera with polluted water • Edward Jenner - smallpox vaccination • Louis Pasteur - the germ theory of disease • James Lind - prevention of scurvy by intake of citrus fruits Louis Pasteur was the first to advance the germ theory of disease, which stated that most diseases 
were caused by microorganisms. This theory was later expanded by Robert Koch, who put forth 
Koch's postulates. Pasteur is also known for the following contributions: • Disproved the theory of spontaneous generation • Developed vaccines for rabies and fowl cholera • Pioneer of techniques of pasteurization and sterilization The following images show Pasteur and Lind respectively: 21 
Sold by @itachibot Scientist/ Doctor

questions.question: Question 16: Who was the architect of the Public Health Act of 1848?
questions.explanation:
Edwin Chadwick was the architect of the Public Health Act of 1848. He was an English lawyer during the 1832 cholera epidemic. He compiled a report on the Sanitary 
Condition of the Labouring Population in Great Britain that eventually led to the passing of this 
act. It is considered a landmark act in the history of public health.

questions.question: Question 17: Identify the scientist who showed that anthrax was caused by a bacteria.
questions.explanation:
Robert Koch discovered that anthrax was caused by bacteria. He also discovered the causative agents of tuberculosis and cholera. He won the Nobel prize in 
Physiology in 1905. He also proposed Koch's postulates linking specific microorganisms to specific diseases. They 
state that the microorganism must be: • Found in abundance in diseased organisms, but not in healthy organisms. • Isolated from a diseased organism and grown in pure culture • Able to cause disease when inoculated into a healthy organism • Re-isolated from the diseased experimental host and identical to the original specific causative 
agent The following images show Robert Koch and his drawing of the anthrax bacillus: 23 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 18: In 1902, it was discovered that malaria was transmitted by the Anopheles mosquito. Who was 
behind this discovery?
questions.explanation:
Ronald Ross showed that malaria was transmitted by Anopheles mosquito. Option B: Charles Alphonse Laveran discovered the malarial parasite. Option C: Walter Reed showed that yellow fever transmitted by Aedes mosquito. Option D: David Bruce showed that African sleeping sickness/trypanosomiasis transmitted by the 
tsetse fly.

questions.question: Question 19: The first bacterium discovered as a cause of the disease was:
questions.explanation:
24 
Sold by @itachibot The first bacterium discovered as a cause of the disease is leprosy bacillus. In 1873, Armauer Hansen demonstrated Mycobacterium leprae (rod-like bodies) from a leprosy 
nodule. This is the first time that chronic infectious disease in humans was shown to be related to 
a bacillus. In 1876, Robert Koch validated the germ theory of disease after discovering the anthrax bacillus 
as the cause of anthrax.

questions.question: Question 20: Max Joseph von Pettenkofer described the concept of:
questions.explanation: Pettenkofer of Munich put forth the theory of multifactorial causation of disease. Other theories of causation of disease include: • Spontaneous generation theory - given by Aristotle • Web of causation theory - given by MacMahon and Pugh • Supernatural theory of disease

questions.question: Question 21: In which country was the last case of naturally occurring smallpox in the world recorded?
questions.explanation:
The last case of naturally occurring smallpox was in Somalia in 1977. The last case of smallpox occurred in 1978 when a medical photographer was accidentally exposed 
to the smallpox virus in a research laboratory in Birmingham. India was declared smallpox-free on 24th May 1975. WHO declared smallpox as eradicated 
globally on 8th May 1980.

questions.question: Question 22: Who first coined the term social medicine?
questions.explanation:
Jules Guérin coined this term as editor of the Gazette médicale de Paris. He was a French 
orthopaedist in the mid-1800s. Option A: John Ryle promoted social medicine in England in the early 1900s. Option C: Alfred Grotjahn described social pathology, the social factors influencing diseases. Option D: Francis Albert Eley Crew stated that social medicine stood on the pillars of medicine 
and sociology.

questions.question: Question 23: How would you define socialized medicine?

options.a: Subsidized medical care at government's expense
options.b: Free medical care provided and regulated by government alone
options.c: Free medical care at government expense, regulated by professional groups
options.d: Integration of social medicine with health care

questions.explanation:
Socialized medicine is the provision of medical service at the government's expense but is 
operated and regulated by professional groups, and not the government. Russia was the first 25 
Sold by @itachibot country to completely socialize medicine. Free medical care by a government alone is called state medicine.

questions.question: Question 24: All of the following are true about socialized medicine except:

options.a: Ensures social equity and universal coverage
options.c: Use state funds for free medicine

questions.explanation:
Increasing the utilization of health services is not a component of socialized medicine. It refers to the provision of medical service through the state funds; however, it is operated and 
regulated by professional groups. Russia was the first to completely socialize medicine. It eliminates competition among physicians as well as ensures social equity and universal health 
coverage.

questions.question: Question 25: Who said that the secret of national health lies in the homes of people?
questions.explanation:
Florence Nightingale said that the secret of national health lies in the homes of people. She is 
considered the the founder of modern nursing. 26 
Sold by @itachibot Health Determinants and Indicators
